info.description:
### Retrieves information about "canonical" courses as approved by the Academic Senate.

The interactive docs below allow you to test parameter usage and see how both requests and return payloads are formatted using the **"Try it out"** feature.

*This feature runs against the UAT version of the API and the QAT version of the source SIS database. Remember to remove "/uat" from the URL to run your client against the production version.*

(Please note, XML responses do *NOT* include the outermost "payload" node shown in this documentation; "apiResponse" is the outermost node. The "payload" node exists, unnamed, *only* in JSON responses.)
info.title: Course API

page-number.name: page-number
page-number.description: The set of records to return; can be used to traverse paginated data sets.

page-size.name: page-size
page-size.description: The number of records returned in one paginated data set. Maximum is 100

app_id.name: app_id
app_id.description: The public ID portion of API Central credentials

app_key.name: app_key
app_key.description: The private key portion of API Central credentials

get.description: Returns course data conforming to the Course EDO described on [bMeta.berkeley.edu](http://bMeta.berkeley.edu)

parameters.name: status-code
parameters.description: A code indicating a course's current state as regards its availability to be offered

parameters.name: subject-area-code
parameters.description: Either a specific code representing an area of academic inquiry covered in the course, e.g., "MATH" -- or a string pattern preceded and/or followed by "%" wildcards, which will match against both the "subjectArea.code" and the "departmentNicknames" (e.g. "%ENGIN%" will return all courses with a subjectArea.code or a departmentNickname that includes the string "ENGIN")

parameters.name: catalog-number
parameters.description: The entire human-readable number for a course, e.g. "C123AC" -- must be an exact match

parameters.name: course-prefix
parameters.description: The alpha character/s preceding the numeric portion of the catalog number, e.g. the first "C" in "C123AC"

parameters.name: course-number
parameters.description: The numeric portion of the catalog number, e.g. "123" in "C123AC"

parameters.name: academic-career-code
parameters.description: The high level grouping of academic policy within UC Berkeley, e.g., "UGRD"

parameters.name: units
parameters.description: An approved unit value for the course (if discrete or a range of values are allowed, this value must be within them)

parameters.name: summer-only
parameters.description: Return only courses offered exclusively during the summer term (defaults to false)

parameters.name: grading-basis-code
parameters.description: A code indicating the method of recording performance in the course

parameters.name: requirement-fulfilled-code
parameters.description: A code indicating a University, Campus, or General Education academic requirement fulfilled when the course is successfully completed

parameters.name: last-updated-since
parameters.description: Return only courses updated since this date (inclusive) – must be in the format "YYYY-MM-DD", e.g., "2021-04-17"

parameters.name: sort-by
parameters.description: Sort the list of courses returned by this element. Valid values are "subject-area-code," "last-updated," and "catalog-number"

        <crs:formerDisplayName/>
        <crs:title>Advanced Projects in Ceramic Sculpture</crs:title>
        <crs:transcriptTitle>ADV PROJ CERAM SCUL</crs:transcriptTitle>
        <crs:description>This advanced course encourages students to stretch the technical limits of ceramic
                    materials and processes. Project assignments will challenge students to develop strong conceptual
                    and material practices, linking their work to larger issues in contemporary art. Topics may include:
                    the intimately handmade, multiples and mass production, conceptual craft, public art, community
                    engagement, interdisciplinary practices, performance, ceramic 3-D printing/modeling, and more.
                    Hands-on demonstrations, field trips, artist lectures, and readings/discussion will accompany
                    dedicated studio time and instruction. Prior experience in clay is expected.</crs:description>

courses.title: The Language of Sculpture
courses.description: A study of how interactions between physical form and the space it generates can serve as a metaphor. Field trips and illustrated talks will help acquaint you with the ideas that sculptors have explored in the 20th century.

primaryInstructionMethod.description: Student practice of studio skills and/or tasks

formatsOffered.description: Six hours of instructional studio and three hours of open studio per week.

instructionMethod.description: Student practice of studio skills and/or tasks
Student practice of studio skills and/or tasks

courses.title: Advanced Projects in Ceramic Sculpture
courses.description: This advanced course encourages students to stretch the technical limits of ceramic materials and processes. Project assignments will challenge students to develop strong conceptual and material practices, linking their work to larger issues in contemporary art. Topics may include: the intimately handmade, multiples and mass production, conceptual craft, public art, community engagement, interdisciplinary practices, performance, ceramic 3-D printing/modeling, and more. Hands-on demonstrations, field trips, artist lectures, and readings/discussion will accompany dedicated studio time and instruction. Prior experience in clay is expected.

primaryInstructionMethod.description: Student practice of studio skills and/or tasks

repeatability.description: Course may be repeated for credit without restriction.

formatsOffered.description: Six hours of studio per week.

instructionMethod.description: Student practice of studio skills and/or tasks
Student practice of studio skills and/or tasks

get.summary: Get course data by unique ID
get.description: Given an ID, returns course data conforming to the Course EDO described on http://bMeta.berkeley.edu

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: Some code or number uniquely identifying the course (no wildcards allowed)

parameters.name: id-type
parameters.description: The type of ID being submitted (if left blank, "displayName" is assumed)

parameters.name: status-code
parameters.description: A code indicating a course's current state as regards its availability to be offered

courses.title: The Language of Sculpture
courses.description: A study of how interactions between physical form and the space it generates can serve as a metaphor. Field trips and illustrated talks will help acquaint you with the ideas that sculptors have explored in the 20th century.

primaryInstructionMethod.description: Student practice of studio skills and/or tasks

formatsOffered.description: Six hours of instructional studio and three hours of open studio per week.

instructionMethod.description: Student practice of studio skills and/or tasks
Student practice of studio skills and/or tasks

courses.title: Advanced Projects in Ceramic Sculpture
courses.description: This advanced course encourages students to stretch the technical limits of ceramic materials and processes. Project assignments will challenge students to develop strong conceptual and material practices, linking their work to larger issues in contemporary art. Topics may include: the intimately handmade, multiples and mass production, conceptual craft, public art, community engagement, interdisciplinary practices, performance, ceramic 3-D printing/modeling, and more. Hands-on demonstrations, field trips, artist lectures, and readings/discussion will accompany dedicated studio time and instruction. Prior experience in clay is expected.
